title: 111_hr6051
content: The Act may be cited as the "Deficit Reduction Through Fair Oil Royalties Act" and pertains to eligibility for new leases and the transfer of leases. The "Deficit Reduction Through Fair Oil Royalties Act" prohibits the issuance of new leases for oil or gas production on the Outer Continental Shelf to lessees unless they renegotiate existing leases to include royalty payments based on specified price thresholds. Lessees must comply to be eligible for new leases. The "Deficit Reduction Through Fair Oil Royalties Act" restricts new lease issuance for oil or gas production on the Outer Continental Shelf to lessees who comply with royalty payment renegotiation requirements based on price thresholds. Lessees with direct or indirect interests in covered leases are subject to the Act, including those who transferred leases after its enactment. Multiple lessees of a covered lease may be treated separately by the Secretary. Beginning on the effective date of an agreement under subparagraph (A), any share subject to the agreement shall not constitute a covered lease with respect to any lessees that entered into the agreement. Lessees with a share of the covered lease may have separate agreements modifying payment responsibilities to include price thresholds equal to or less than those in the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act. Transfers of covered leases in the Gulf of Mexico under the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act are restricted for lessees or individuals benefiting from the lease unless they renegotiate the lease to include payment thresholds equal to or less than those specified in the Act. The Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act restricts transfers of covered leases in the Gulf of Mexico unless lessees agree to include royalty relief limitations based on market prices. Amounts received from rentals or royalties must be used for Federal budget deficit reduction or reducing the Federal debt. The term "covered lease" in the Gulf of Mexico refers to existing leases for oil or gas production issued by the Department of the Interior under specific conditions. The term "lessee" includes any person involved in these leases. The term "lessee" includes any person or entity that controls, is controlled by, or is in common control with a lessee. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. The Secretary of the Interior can amend leases for Gulf of Mexico tracts from 1996 to 2000 to include price thresholds for royalty suspension provisions. The new thresholds will be effective from October 1, 2010, while existing provisions will remain until September 30, 2010.
